extracted.value: Appeal: United States of America appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit

evidence.text: The United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA.
The United States also seeks an order preliminarily and permanently enjoining Idaho’s restrictive abortion law to the extent it conflicts with EMTALA.
Plaintiff: United States of America

evidence.text: PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION
IT IS ORDERED ... DENIED
The panel granted the Idaho Legislature’s motion to stay, pending appeal, the district court’s order preliminarily enjoining Idaho Code section 18-622

Pursuant to Fed R. Civ P. 41(a)(1)(A)(ii), Plaintiff the United States of America, along with Defendant the State of Idaho and Defendant-Intervenor the Idaho Legislature, hereby stipulate to the dismissal, without prejudice, of all of the United States’ claims in this action, each party to bear their own attorney’s fees and costs.
DATED: August 13, 2022
DATED: August 17, 2022
DATED: August 24, 2022
DATED: September 28, 2023
DATED: May 4, 2023

Pursuant to Fed R. Civ P. 41(a)(1)(A)(ii), Plaintiff the United States of America, along with Defendant the State of Idaho and Defendant-Intervenor the Idaho Legislature, hereby stipulate to the dismissal, without prejudice, of all of the United States’ claims in this action, each party to bear their own attorney’s fees and costs.

In this action, the United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA. The law, codified at Idaho Code § 18-622, is currently set to take effect on August 25, 2022, which is 30 days after the Supreme Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, 142 S. Ct. 2228 (2022).

extracted.value: Idaho’s abortion law, effective August 25, 2022, criminalizes abortions and conflicts with EMTALA’s requirement to provide stabilizing medical treatment for patients in emergency situations.

evidence.text: __________________________ B. Lynn Winmill U.S. District Court Judge

evidence.text: Pursuant to Fed R. Civ P. 41(a)(1)(A)(ii), Plaintiff the United States of America, along with Defendant the State of Idaho and Defendant-Intervenor the Idaho Legislature, hereby stipulate to the dismissal, without prejudice, of all of the United States’ claims in this action, each party to bear their own attorney’s fees and costs.
Under the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd
EMTALA contains an express preemption provision, which preempts State laws “to the extent that the requirement directly conflicts with a requirement of this section.” 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd(f)
The law, codified at Idaho Code § 18-622, is currently set to take effect on August 25, 2022
The United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA.

Pursuant to Fed R. Civ P. 41(a)(1)(A)(ii), Plaintiff the United States of America, along with Defendant the State of Idaho and Defendant-Intervenor the Idaho Legislature, hereby stipulate to the dismissal, without prejudice, of all of the United States’ claims in this action, each party to bear their own attorney’s fees and costs.
